April 27, 2003: Fiction
ARMAGEDDON, by Tim LaHaye and Jerry B. Jenkins. (Tyndale, $24.99.) The
11th volume of the "Left Behind" series, in which the forces of good battle the
forces of evil after the rapture of the saved.
THE GUARDIAN, by Nicholas Sparks. (Warner, $24.95.) While trying to choose
between two suitors, a young widow realizes that her life is in danger.
BIRTHRIGHT, by Nora Roberts. (Putnam, $25.95.) An archaeologist on a dig in
Maryland is forced to confront troubling questions about her past.
THE DA VINCI CODE, by Dan Brown. (Doubleday, $24.95.) The murder of a
curator at the Louvre leads to a trail of clues found in the work of Leonardo and to
the discovery of a centuries-old secret society.
LOST LIGHT, by Michael Connelly. (Little, Brown, $25.95.) The former Los
Angeles homicide detective Harry Bosch unofficially reopens a cold case involving
a 24-year-old woman who was strangled.
THE KING OF TORTS, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $27.95.) A public defender
in Washington happens upon a frightening conspiracy involving one of the largest
pharmaceutical companies in the world.
CERULEAN SINS, by Laurell K. Hamilton. (Berkley, $22.95.) A vampire hunter
finds herself the consort of both the master vampire and a wereleopard.
THE LOVELY BONES, by Alice Sebold. (Little, Brown, $21.95.) A 14-year-old girl
looks down from heaven as she describes what happens in the aftermath of her
kidnapping and murder.
DEAD AIM, by Iris Johansen. (Bantam, $24.95.) On assignment in Colorado, a
famous photojournalist becomes the target of killers after she discovers a terrifying
conspiracy.
THE JESTER, by James Patterson and Andrew Gross. (Little, Brown, $27.95.)
Upon returning home from the First Crusade, an innkeeper learns that his son has
been killed and his wife has been abducted.
CHILDREN OF THE STORM, by Elizabeth Peters. (Morrow, $25.95.) In 1919, the
archaeologist Amelia Peabody investigates theft and murder in Egypt.
DATING GAME, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $26.95.) After her husband leaves
her, a 46-year-old woman decides what to do with the rest of her life.
THE RELUCTANT SUITOR, by Kathleen E. Woodiwiss. (Morrow, $24.95.) A 19th-
century Englishwoman pines for a man to whom she has long been betrothed.
TWELVE TIMES BLESSED, by Jacquelyn Mitchard. (HarperCollins, $25.95.) The
April 27, 2003
Non-Fiction
WHAT SHOULD I DO WITH MY LIFE? by Po Bronson. (Random House, $24.95.)
The stories of 55 people who found their calling after years of struggle.
LEAP OF FAITH, by Queen Noor. (Miramax, $25.95.) An autobiography by the
widow of King Hussein of Jordan.
STUPID WHITE MEN, by Michael Moore. (ReganBooks/HarperCollins, $24.95.)
The man behind "Roger & Me" takes aim at Republicans and Democrats,
corporate America and our "nation of idiots."
DERELICTION OF DUTY, by Robert (Buzz) Patterson. (Regnery, $27.95.) A
retired Air Force colonel who served in the White House contends that Bill Clinton
"compromised America's national security."
THE SAVAGE NATION, by Michael Savage. (WND/ Thomas Nelson, $24.99.) A
radio talk show host proposes to save America from "the liberal assault on our
borders, language and culture."
JARHEAD, by Anthony Swofford. (Scribner, $24.) A memoir of the 1991 Persian
Gulf war by a former Marine sniper.
THE CRISIS OF ISLAM, by Bernard Lewis. (Modern Library, $19.95.) A scholar of
Middle Eastern history (and author of "What Went Wrong?") meditates on "holy
war and unholy terror."
I AM THE CENTRAL PARK JOGGER, by Trisha Meili. (Scribner, $25.) The
woman who was raped, beaten and left for dead on the night of April 19, 1989,
tells her story.
THE DEVIL IN THE WHITE CITY, by Erik Larson. (Crown, $25.95.) The tale of a
great architect (Daniel Hudson Burnham) and a serial killer (H. H. Holmes), who
were linked by the Chicago World's Fair of 1893.
OF PARADISE AND POWER, by Robert Kagan. (Knopf, $18.) A scholar analyzes
the changing relationship between Europe and the United States.
THE HUNT FOR BIN LADEN, by Robin Moore. (Random House, $24.95.) The
war in Afghanistan as seen through the eyes of members of the Special Forces;
by the author of "The Green Berets."
GOOD TO GREAT, by Jim Collins. (HarperBusiness, $27.50.) Why some
companies thrive and others do not.
USEFUL IDIOTS, by Mona Charen. (Regnery, $27.95.) The columnist and
television commentator goes on the attack against liberals, who "got it wrong in
the cold war and still blame America first."
